sect1.title: Quick start
sect1.para: This section will quickly get you started with JSure. It describes how to install JSure into your Eclipse, how to install a license file that allows you to use JSure. It also describes how to enable JSure assurane of a Java project, and how to examine the assurance results.

sect2.title: Installing Your License
sect2.para: This section assumes that you have installed JSure. If you see a JSure menu item on your Eclipse main menu then you can assume JSure has been installed properly.

You need to install a license to use JSure. If you do not have a license file that was sent to you by SureLogic visit http://www.surelogic.com to obtain one. To install the license select Manage SureLogic Licenses from the JSure menu as shown in

figure.title: The menu option to install a license for JSure

sect2.para: This will cause the Manage SureLogic Licenses window to appear as shown in . Highlight the JSure row and select the Install License button to install your license file.

JSure will not disrupt your Eclipse installation if a license for it is not installed, however, it will not allow you to use JSure functionality. We will assume from this point on that you have installed your license. For more information, see

sect2.title: Annotating and Assuring Your Code
sect2.para: For the impatient, this section provides a “bare-bones” description of how to prepare a Java project for assurance by JSure.

JSure assurance compares Java code against programmer design intent as expressed using a set of Java 5 annotation types. To use JSure with your code, your project must be able to reference the SureLogic annotation types. The SureLogic annotation types are bundled together in promises.jar. This file must be on the build path of your project for the annotations be to used. As described below, the simplest way to add this JAR file to the project and its build path is to allow JSure to do it for you.

sect3.title: Enabling JSure Analysis
sect3.para:
JSure can only assure the contents of one project at a time. The icon of the project being assured is marked with a small S (for SureLogic) in the lower right corner: . The easiest way to select the project to assure is to
Select the project in the Package Explorer.
Press the icon in the view’s toolbar. This same action is also available as Focus Verificaton on this Project in the view’s menu.
If any other project is currently selected for assurance, this action first disables assurance on that project before enabling the newly selected project.

When a project is selected for analysis, JSure checks to see if promises.jar is on the project’s build path. If it is not, it offers to add the file to the project and the build path:
The easiest thing to do is to choose the default option Add to Project Root: JSure copies promises.jar to the root of project and adds it to the build path. See for more details.

sect3.title: Disabling JSure Analysis
sect3.para:
To deselect a project without selecting another project to assure
Select the project in the Package Explorer.
Press the icon in the view’s toolbar. This same action is also available as Disable Verificaton in the view’s menu.
Disabling analysis of a project does not affect promises.jar or the project’s build path.

sect3.title: Viewing Assurance Results
sect3.para:
JSure reassures the chosen project whenever a file in that project is changed. This guarantees that the assurance results are always up to date. The assurance results are displayed in the Verification Status view. The easiest way to open this view is to switch to the Code Verification perspective. The first time you enable JSure analysis on any project in the workspace JSure prompts you about switching to the Code Verification perspective:
Choosing Yes will immediately switch Eclipse to the perspective. Choosing No will leave the current Eclipse window in whatever perspective it is currently in. If you check Remember my decision and press Yes then whenever you focus verificaton on a project, Eclipse will switch to the perspective without asking you first.
You can also switch to the Code Verification perspective by selecting JSure Open Code Verification Perspective. See .

The code verification perspective defaults to showing the Package Explorer and Verification Status views; see . The Verification Status view is divided into sections to show the results of assuring different classes of design intent, such as effects, and concurrency, as well as showing less specific suggestions and warnings. The various result messages are explained in detail in .
